story.storybody:
Published in the Biology of Sex Differences, a research has revealed that women who are trying to quit smoking should consider 'timing' it in around their periods.

The research that was carried out by a set of researchers from the Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania also elucidates on how women are more prone to the harmful effects smoking brings with itself: "including a 25 per cent increased risk of developing coronary heart disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease."

Researchers have also mentioned that women find it tougher than men to give up smoking.

Also Read: Now passive smoking could lead to infertility and early menopause

Reagan Wetherill, the study's lead author, states, "Understanding how menstrual cycle phase affects neural processes, cognition and behaviour is a critical step in developing more effective treatments and in selecting the best, most individualised treatment options to help each cigarette smoker quit."

During the course of the aforementioned study, it was found out that the sex hormones, estrogen and progesterone (which fluctuate during the menstrual cycle) "modulate addictive behaviour," Science Daily reports. In easier terms, it is these sex hormones in the female body that command up to a great degree whether or not women will or will not get addicted to a particular substance (including edibles).

Also Read: Here's how you could fight Asthma by altering your lifestyle in 6 ways

With a set of 38 physically healthy, pre-menopausal women who smoke, aged between 21-51 years of age, on board, the study involved a "functional MRI scan to examine how regions of the brain that help control behaviour are functionally connected to regions of the brain that signal reward."

Analysing the results of the research revealed that it was easier for women to quit smoking during the pre-menstrual phase of their cycle, which is when "addictive behaviours are thwarted". Alternately, women might find it tougher to give up on their smoking addiction during the pre-ovulatory phase--that is, a few days after their period ends.
